confession.seduction_context: Angered by her children, met devil in garden behind house. Usual seduction scene - gave her a piece of money which turned into a leaf
powder_types: received powder twice, threw it away at cost of a beating
sabbat_activities: carried up into air by master when making hail

testimony.quarrel_subject: Contract to cart manure for her husband - she secretly loaded more than agreed
She marveled at seeing his cows so fat and in good state, suggested he must be feeding them oats; he replied harshly that his oats were for his horses, not his cows
testimony.threat_quote: elle estoit tout esmerveillée de veoir ses vaches sy gras at en si bon estat, et qu'il n'estoit pas possible qu'il ne leur donne de l'avoine

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: next day (first cow), followed quickly by second

testimony.quarrel_subject: His daughter asked if Clemence wanted to heat her poisle for women and girls to spin; she said no. Then Clemence came while they were eating dinner asking why his daughter wasn't coming to her poisle; he replied harshly that he didn't want to be bothered during dinner and told her to leave

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 5 or 6 weeks after the cows died

testimony.quarrel_subject: 16-17 years before, he and other boys returning from pasture had passed through her garden; she was angry and spoke ill of him in his absence
Did not want to go to Clemence's poisle
Quarrel over poisle; Clemence called his sister 'glorieuse' and said they would all repent
testimony.threat_quote: que s'il leur arrivoit quelque mauvais accident que ne seroit pas tout ung, et qu'ilz luy soupconneroient
qu'elle avoit esté seduicte par ung mauvais mariage

witnesses.name: Claudon Crounesier dit le Grand Claudon
Demenge Marchal
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: business rival (same trade as her husband)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Various quarrels; believed she bore him envy because he pursued same trade as her husband

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: shortly after Clemence was around her

testimony.threat_quote: disoit ce qu'il vouloit et que sy elle avoit ung bon soustenant, elle l'en feroit bien ressentir

witnesses.name: Jean le Clerc
witnesses.occupation: sergent en la justice de Domjevin

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: died 18 days after receiving last sacraments

testimony.threat_quote: qu'il avoit oppinion que ladite prevenue sa mere auroit plustost fait mourir le pere du mary de ladite depposante que son propre pere

witnesses.name: Jean Francois
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor from her place of origin

witnesses.name: Lucye veuve Claudon Pierson
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor, husband worked with accused's husband

testimony.quarrel_subject: Various trivial disputes between husband and accused's husband over forging
Various quarrels 16 years before when witness lived next to accused and ran father's household
testimony.threat_quote: qu'elle couroit bien fort, mais qu'elle ne coureroit pas tousjours sy fort, et laisseroit bien faire les autres

witnesses.name: Francois Cherier
witnesses.occupation: sergent en la justice de Blamont

timeline.subject: Clemence Marchal
timeline.details: Torture with thumbscrews and rack; confessed to incest with son but not witchcraft

timeline.subject: Clemence Marchal
timeline.details: Wanted to confess to witchcraft; confessed under torture to seduction by devil, sabbat attendance, making hail, but denied malefices and accomplices

timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for further torture or execution

timeline.subject: Clemence Marchal
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to execution

timeline.subject: Clemence Marchal
timeline.details: Execution carried out

torture.restrictions: First approved for thumbscrews only; later approved for full torture

prior_accusations.context: Executed at Blamont 12-13 years before (circa 1590-1591); denounced Clemence. She was in childbed at the time which saved her from arrest
Currently prisoner at Blamont at time of trial; witness had deposed against her 13 years earlier
Mentioned as deceased; witness had deposed against her 13 years earlier

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Henry (witness 3)
notable_quotes.french: que'elle estoit tout esmerveillée de veoir ses vaches sy gras at en si bon estat, et qu'il n'estoit pas possible qu'il ne leur donne de l'avoine, a laquelle il fit response assé rigoreuse que son avoine estoit pour ses chevaux, et non pour ses vaches
notable_quotes.english: that she was all amazed to see his cows so fat and in such good state, and that it was not possible that he did not give them oats, to which he made a rather harsh response that his oats were for his horses, and not for his cows
notable_quotes.context: Quarrel preceding death of two cows

notable_quotes.speaker: Clemence to Jean Henry
notable_quotes.french: dequoy elle se formallisoit disant qu'elle n'estoit pas telle femme
notable_quotes.english: at which she took offense saying that she was not such a woman
notable_quotes.context: Response when called a witch and blamed for cow deaths

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Godot (witness 4)
notable_quotes.french: et voyant ledit deposant qu'elle parloit rigoreusement, il luy respondit avec mesme rigueur, qu'il ne vouloit pas estre importuné sur son disner qu'elle sorte de sa maison, laquelle respondit qu'il s'en repentiroit et se pensoit en luy mesme, que sy c'estoit ung homme il luy romperoit la teste
notable_quotes.english: and seeing that she spoke harshly, he replied with equal harshness, that he did not want to be bothered during his dinner, that she should leave his house, to which she replied that he would regret it and he thought to himself, that if it were a man he would break his head
notable_quotes.context: Quarrel over poisle, preceding animal deaths

notable_quotes.speaker: Clemence's husband (reported by witness 11)
notable_quotes.french: qu'est ce qu'on disoit de ces pauvres femmes prisonnieres disant que ladite Clemence sa femme les abuseroit
notable_quotes.english: what are they saying about these poor imprisoned women, saying that Clemence his wife would abuse them

notable_quotes.speaker: Clemence
notable_quotes.french: belles gens oyez ce fol cy ce qu'il dit sans se donner grande peine
notable_quotes.english: good people hear this fool what he says without giving it much thought
notable_quotes.context: Clemence's response to her husband's comment

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Wamiot (witness 10)
notable_quotes.french: que s'il leur arrivoit quelque mauvais accident que ne seroit pas tout ung, et qu'ilz luy soupconneroient
notable_quotes.english: that if any misfortune should happen to them it would not be all the same, and that they would suspect her
notable_quotes.context: Witness warning Clemence after calling her witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Clemence to Jean du Pont
notable_quotes.french: disoit ce qu'il vouloit et que sy elle avoit ung bon soustenant, elle l'en feroit bien ressentir
notable_quotes.english: he said what he wanted and that if she had a good supporter, she would make him feel it
notable_quotes.context: Response when Demenge Niclas called her witch and blamed her for damage

notable_quotes.speaker: Estienne Louyot's father (witness 18)
notable_quotes.french: qui luy deffendit sur peine de la vye de n'en dire mot de poeur de la scandalliser
notable_quotes.english: who forbade him on pain of death not to say a word for fear of scandalizing her
notable_quotes.context: Father's warning after son witnessed Clemence disappear with man in black on horse

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Marchal d'Embermesnil (witness 27)
notable_quotes.french: et qu'il avoit oppinion qu'ilz ne pouvoient mourir qu'ils ne fussent bruslé, a quoy replicqua icelle prevenue qu'ilz en mouroient beaucoups sans estre bruslé et qu'elle le scavoit bien
notable_quotes.english: and that he had the opinion that they could not die unless they were burned, to which the accused replied that many of them died without being burned and that she knew it well
notable_quotes.context: Conversation about whether witches had to be burned to die

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon l'Hoste (witness 36)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle couroit bien fort, mais qu'elle ne coureroit pas tousjours sy fort, et laisseroit bien faire les autres
notable_quotes.english: that she ran very fast, but that she would not always run so fast, and would let others do it
notable_quotes.context: Clemence's threat to Jennon before she developed crippling thigh trouble

notable_quotes.speaker: Clemence at arrest
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle avoit esté seduicte par ung mauvais mariage
notable_quotes.english: that she had been seduced by a bad marriage
notable_quotes.context: Cryptic remark at arrest that officials hoped would lead to confession

notable_quotes.speaker: Clemence (elaboration)
notable_quotes.french: que scavoit esté ad cause d'un mariage par ce que l'on ne luy avoit voulu donner ung jeune homme qu'elle aymoit fort a Embermesnil
notable_quotes.english: that she knew it was because of a marriage because they would not give her a young man whom she loved very much at Embermesnil

notable_quotes.speaker: Someone to young Clemence
notable_quotes.french: il est vray qu'elle aymoit ung jeune garson dudit Embermesnil nomme Estienne et qu'on luy dit estante encore jeune fille maudisoit son bruict, sans ce mauvais bruict que vous avez, tu l'aurois en mariage
notable_quotes.english: it is true that she loved a young boy from Embermesnil named Estienne and they told her when she was still a young girl cursed her reputation, without this bad reputation that you have, you would have him in marriage
notable_quotes.context: Explanation of why she couldn't marry the man she loved

relationships.evidence_text: daughter of Jean Jacquemin and Alison Niclass
Had heard her relative Demenge Niclas call her witch
had served her for 2 and a half years
Had served her husband as apprentice for a year
native of Ambermesnil, neighbour of her father

economic_context.details: Demenge Marchal (witness 17) believed Clemence bore him envy because he pursued the same trade (blacksmith) as her husband. Dispute with Demenge Niclas over contract to cart manure where she allegedly loaded more than agreed. Shared plough team arrangement with Jean le Clerc.

harms_catalog.victim_name: two cows belonging to Jean Henry
harms_catalog.harm_description: One cow had trouble with hind leg and died same day, followed quickly by the other with foreleg trouble
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Clemence marveled at his fat cows and suggested he must feed them oats; he replied harshly his oats were for horses not cows

harms_catalog.victim_name: two cows belonging to Nicolas Godot
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Quarrel over heating poisle for spinning; she was told to leave during dinner and said he would regret it

harms_catalog.victim_name: two heifers belonging to Nicolas Godot
harms_catalog.harm_description: lost milk and died after 15 days
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: 5 or 6 weeks after the cows died

harms_catalog.harm_description: illness affecting right leg below ankle, with holes appearing; was 'un mal mangeant' which caused great pain
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: He and other boys passed through her garden; she was angry and spoke ill of him
Quarrel over poisle, called his sister 'glorieuse'

harms_catalog.victim_name: wife of Jean Marchal (sister-in-law of witness)
harms_catalog.harm_description: fell sick and died in a week
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Various quarrels between Clemence and Demenge Marchal
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: immediately after Clemence was around her

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Envy because he pursued same trade as her husband
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: shortly after Clemence was around her

harms_catalog.harm_description: died some 18 days after receiving last sacraments, had been ill for 8 years
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: None mentioned; surgeon said Clemence was a bad woman

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill with headaches etc, bedridden 6 weeks

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Various trivial disputes over forging work

harms_catalog.harm_description: developed trouble in a thigh, constant pain and virtually crippled
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Various quarrels when living next door

material_culture.context: Contract to cart manure for her husband
Multiple witnesses report deaths of cows
Nicolas Godot's heifers lost milk and died
Quarrel over feeding oats to cows vs horses
Women and girls would gather to spin by heated poisle according to local custom
Quarrel over a coat lost by son of accused, to whom it had been lent
Egyptian healer gave ointments which cured Henry Mulnier's leg
Egyptian healer said he needed to obtain bread and yeast from Clemence's house to cure illness
Jean Marchal was heating a charcoal furnace for his brother
Clemence asked if he could go to Reillon with her to take some yarn to a weaver
Going to see some cloth at weaver
Shared plough team between Clemence and Jean le Clerc
Went together to field to cart hay
Clemence offered a dozen eggs as payment to surgeon
Story of Clemence and her mother being seen dancing with a broom in their hands

material_culture.object: device made with cloth and a stick
material_culture.context: Mother placed under nut-tree to chase off crows
Confessed to receiving powder twice from devil, threw it away at cost of a beating

material_culture.object: piece of money which turned into a leaf
material_culture.context: Devil gave her piece of money which turned into leaf during seduction

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial, where accused lived for 26 years
Accused's birthplace and origin; where she and her mother had reputation as witches
Court location where trial was conducted and execution carried out
Where Jean Colin's mother made second marriage
Where Clemence wanted to take yarn to weaver, location of supernatural encounter
Where Clemence and Estienne Louyot sat to rest, where man in black on horse appeared
Where Demenge Marchal was when his wife died
Home of surgeon who attended Andre Pierson's wife
Home of witness Jennon femme Claudon l'Hoste
Home of witnesses Jean Ferry and wife Catherine
Home of Brehier, burned at Blamont as a witch
Where Clemence claimed to have been seduced by devil named Guillot; also where boys passed through causing quarrel
Where Jean Henry was taking cows; where boys were returning from
Where Jean le Clerc and Clemence went to cart hay
Location of Change de Nancy court that approved torture and execution

weather_events: great wind and cloud that came up when carting hay
economic_hardship_indicators: shared plough teams indicating limited resources
concern over animal deaths representing economic losses

prior_legal_disputes.description: Quarrel over coat lost by son of accused, to whom it had been lent, with son of Nicolas Godot

legal_context.redress_outcome: Demenge Niclas called her witch and she took no action against him; Jean du Pont reported she said if she had a good supporter she would make people feel it for calling her witch
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Imprisoned at Blamont; claimed to have seen 'une clarté' at night which lasted two hours and was the grace of God

hearsay_chains.content: She had been angry and spoke ill of him in his absence, as he had been told
Over last two weeks had heard from Nicolas Goudat that illness in daughter's leg had been identified as her work by a devin
Her son Demenge had told witness 'qu'il avoit oppinion que ladite prevenue sa mere auroit plustost fait mourir le pere du mary de ladite depposante que son propre pere'
Both she and her mother had reputation of being witches at Embermesnil; story of their both being seen dancing with a broom in their hands
Allison had told her that a black dog often came down their chimney
Told of daughter Allison's story about black dog
Had only heard talk about her since accusation by Mengin Lours
Repeated story told by brother; he himself had been away at Ogreviller and heard it on return

emotional_state_notes: Eventually confessed under torture but only after being racked
Daughter Allison wept saying her mother was innocent

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Recognized Nicolas Godot as 'homme de bien pourveu qu'il puisse avoir accord avec ses voisins'; suggested his animals had died more than 4 years back
Claimed Henry Mulnier was commonly a liar
Suggested that wife of Jean Marchal was already ill when she spoke with her

third_parties.name: Mengin Lours
third_parties.context: Executed at Blamont 12-13 years before; denounced Clemence but she was in childbed at the time which saved her from arrest

third_parties.name: Jennon
third_parties.context: Currently prisoner at Blamont at time of trial; brought to suggest Clemence should confess during first torture session

third_parties.name: Chrestienne femme Jean Diez
third_parties.context: Deceased; witness Zabey had deposed against her 13 years earlier

third_parties.name: Pierre (Egipsien/Egyptian)
third_parties.context: Traveling healer who identified Henry Mulnier's illness and provided ointments that cured him; said he needed bread and yeast from Clemence's house

third_parties.name: surgeon from Marieviller
third_parties.context: Attended wife of Andre Pierson; said Clemence was a bad woman when she asked for ointment

third_parties.name: man in black on powerful black horse
third_parties.context: Estienne Louyot witnessed Clemence disappear with this figure near a spring by a wood 25 years earlier

third_parties.name: Brehier from Domepvre
third_parties.context: Burned at Blamont as a witch 18 years before; conversation about his execution

third_parties.name: la Marievillée
third_parties.context: From Embermesnil; deceased; Clemence allegedly said she knew this woman had died without being burned and had made calves die

third_parties.name: devin (fortune-teller)
third_parties.context: Identified illness in Nicolas Godot's daughter's leg as Clemence's work

third_parties.name: Claudon (son of accused)
third_parties.context: Aged about 20; shared bed with mother for 7 years; Clemence confessed to incest with him; he was arrested, interrogated, tortured but denied charges and was eventually released

third_parties.name: Estienne (young man from Embermesnil)
third_parties.context: Young man Clemence loved at Embermesnil whom she was not allowed to marry because of her bad reputation

third_parties.name: Victor (brother of Estienne Louyot)
third_parties.context: Estienne Louyot told him about the supernatural encounter after hearing of accusation

third_parties.name: Colas Godat
third_parties.context: Had number of animals dead after disputes with Clemence

extraction_metadata.notes: This is an exceptionally well-documented trial with 43 witnesses over two rounds of depositions. The case is notable for: (1) Clemence withstanding first round of torture without confessing to witchcraft; (2) prosecutor recommending release for lack of evidence; (3) second round of depositions ordered; (4) focus shifting to incest accusation with her son; (5) final confession to witchcraft only under second torture but refusing to name accomplices or admit malefices; (6) execution despite incomplete confession; (7) son interrogated, tortured but released after denying incest. The trial reveals extensive reputation spanning 12-30 years, triggered by denunciation from executed witch Mengin Lours. Multiple quarrels over economic disputes (manure contract, trade rivalry, animal care, poisle use) preceded alleged harms. Supernatural elements include witness seeing her disappear with man in black 25 years earlier, story of dancing with broom, black dog down chimney. The case demonstrates how long-standing reputation, economic tensions, and prior accusations created vulnerable position leading to conviction despite resistance under torture.
